Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure that super/sub classes can both update an animation binding in harmony
Issues.Body:
In ivy, because metadata is inherited, this may cause super and sub host bindings on
two components to update an animation binding in parallel. This patch ensures that
the animation transition code can handle this.

Jira-Issue: FW-1220
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): ensure that super/sub classes can both update an animation binding in harmony" (#30022)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngcc - do not copy declaration files into bundle clone
Issues.Body:
Previously, all of a program's files would be copied into the __ivy_ngcc__
folder where ngcc then writes its modifications into. The set of source files
in a program however is much larger than the source files contained within
the entry-point of interest, so many more files were copied than necessary.
Even worse, it may occur that an unrelated file in the program would collide
with an already existing source file, resulting in incorrectly overwriting
a file with unrelated content. This behavior has actually been observed
with @angular/animations and @angular/platform-browser/animations, where
the former package would overwrite declaration files of the latter package.

This commit fixes the issue by only copying relevant source files when cloning
a bundle's content into __ivy_ngcc__.

Fixes #29960
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): ngcc - do not copy declaration files into bundle clone" (#30020)

Issues.Title: fix(common): suggest keyvalue pipe in error thrown when trying to use NgFor with an object
Issues.Body:
The error messaging in NgFor will now point developers toward the keyvalue pipe when they try to iterate over an object. This is valuable to developers who may not know about the new feature (introduced in 6.1).

fixes #28240

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [ X ] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ X ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ X ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

When a developer tries to pass an object to NgFor, the error message does not mention the keyvalue pipe, which would allow iterating over an object's properties. 

Issue Number: 28240

## What is the new behavior?

The error handler returns the same message as before for invalid values passed into NgFor. 

If the invalid value is an object and not null, the handler will return the same error message, but with "Use the keyvalue pipe to iterate over an object's properties" appended.

The [schematics for libraries guide](https://angular.io/guide/schematics-for-libraries) uses the `cp` command to copy schematics into the library's output directory (in the `package.json` file). Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngcc - prefer JavaScript source files when resolving module‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶ imports

Packages that do not follow APF may have the declaration files in the same
directory as one source format, typically ES5. This is problematic for ngcc,
as it needs to create a TypeScript program with all JavaScript sources of
an entry-point, whereas TypeScript's module resolution mechanism would have
resolved an internal module import to the external facing .d.ts declaration
file, instead of the JavaScript source file. This behavior results in the
program to be analysed being incomplete.

This commit introduces a custom compiler host that recognizes the above
scenario and rewires the resolution of a .d.ts declaration file to its
JavaScript counterpart, if applicable.

Fixes #29939
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): ngcc - prefer JavaScript source files when resolving module‚Ä¶" (#30017)

Issues.Title: feat(router): Descendant projection through router.
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request ### Relevant Package This feature request is for @angular/router, @angular/core ### Description Basically, my feature request is about content projection through router tree. I'll explain with an example. Let's say I have an Tab Component which contains a basic **"two tab"** **mat-tab-nav-bar**. Also, I have two other components which contain my real page contents. In this case, my router configuration would be something like so ```typescript { path: 'identity', component: TabsComponent children: [ { path: 'tab1', component: Tab1Component }, { path: 'tab2', component: Tab2Component } ] } ``` My TabsComponent has an **@ContentChildren** query with descendants option true. TabsComponents template looks like this. ```html
Tab1 Tab2
``` So each tab component has an ng-template something like so ```html Content will be projected to anchestor component ``` ### Describe the solution you'd like Content projection should work as the current content projection works with descendant components. ### Describe alternatives you've considered My workaround. Each tab has an variable named as toolbar which has a @ViewChild('toolbar') decorator. So all tab pages takes their ng-template reference by theirselves. So TabsComponents template looks like this. ```html ... ``` Hint: Don't know whether this already solved by ivy. Thanks
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(router): Descendant projection through router." (#30016)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): queries not being inherited from undecorated classes
Issues.Body:
Fixes view and content queries not being inherited in Ivy, if the base class hasn't been annotated with an Angular decorator (e.g. `Component` or `Directive`).

Also reworks the way the `ngBaseDef` is created so that it is added at the same point as the queries, rather than inside of the `Input` and `Output` decorators.

This PR partially resolves FW-1275. Support for host bindings will be added in a follow-up, because this PR is somewhat large as it is.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): queries not being inherited from undecorated classes" (#30015)

Issues.Title: feat(core): add undecorated-base-class migration schematic
Issues.Body:
Introduces a new upgrade schematic that automatically decorates
`@Directive` / `@Component` base classes that use dependency injection
with the `@Directive` decorator. The new dummy directives are also
added to the corresponding "NgModule" declarations in order to not
cause any compilation warnings.

Adding the `@Directive` decorator ensures that "ngtsc" can properly
create the needed Ivy fields so that dependency injection works
as expected once Ivy is enabled in the application.

References FW-1238

---

Things that need to be handled in follow-ups:

1) Warn if the base class is not exported/or add the export modifier
automatically.
2) Create Google3 tslint rule. In favor of keeping the PR as clear as possible, the G3 tslint rule
should be created in a follow-up.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(core): add undecorated-base-class migration schematic" (#30012)

Issues.Title: ci: remove integration test "uname -a" command
Issues.Body:
We recently added the "uname -a" command to the CircleCI
integration test in order to identify Linux kernels that
broke Chrome sandboxing.

Since this issue seems to be claimed as fixed by the CircleCI
support and we didn't see any sandboxing issues the last month,
we are removing the debugging command we added.

See: https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/80379697e2755fadb313512654291891f1851659

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): classes should not mess up matching for bound dir attributes
Issues.Body:
Previously, we had a bug where directive matching could fail if the directive
                              attribute was bound and followed a certain number of classes. This is because
                              in the matching logic, we were treating classes like normal attributes. We 
                              should instead be skipping classes in the attribute matching logic. Otherwise 
                              classes will match for directives with attribute selectors, and as we are 
                              iterating through them in twos (when they are stored as name-only, not in 
                              name-value pairs), it may throw off directive matching for any bound attributes 
                              that come after. This commit changes the directive matching logic to skip 
                              classes altogether.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): classes should not mess up matching for bound dir attributes" (#30002)

Issues.Title: fix(core): Fix Type<T> for strictFunctionTypes
Issues.Body:
See - https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/24428
tl;dr - When using `--strict` mode, `any` isn't a subtype of `string`
and thus the function doesn't match types.

Fixes #29905

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

Current definition for `Type<T>` uses `any[]` for the `new` function, however this doesn't work well with `strictFunctionTypes` because for example `new(foo:string)` isn't assignable because `any` isn't a subtype of string.

See - https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/24428

Issue Number: #29905


## What is the new behavior?

`Type<T>` now uses `never[]` which means we can't instantiate with `new` whatever we cast to `Type<T>` but now it should be assignable because `never` is a subtype of `string`

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->

Issues.Title: xi18n doesn't emit messages.xlf with Ivy enabled
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [x] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? The issue is only present with Ivy enabled ### Description Running `ng xi18n` does not emit `messages.xlf` if the app uses Ivy. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` ng new xi18n --defaults --enable-ivy cd xi18n # add i18n attribute on the h1 tag in app.component.html ng xi18n ``` ## üî• Exception or Error No error can be seen, the command runs OK: 

Hash: d2b856c9dffb86f8809b
Time: 16592ms
Built at: 21/04/2019 15:44:26
           Asset      Size         Chunks                    Chunk Names
         main.js  2.19 MiB           main  [emitted]  [big]  main
polyfills-es5.js   361 KiB  polyfills-es5  [emitted]  [big]  polyfills-es5
    polyfills.js   151 KiB      polyfills  [emitted]         polyfills
Entrypoint main [big] = main.js
Entrypoint polyfills-es5 [big] = polyfills-es5.js
Entrypoint polyfills = polyfills.js
chunk {main} main.js (main) 1.81 MiB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {polyfills} polyfills.js (polyfills) 146 KiB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {polyfills-es5} polyfills-es5.js (polyfills-es5) 193 KiB [entry] [rendered]
But not file is emmited. If you switch `enableIvy` to `false`, then the command emits `messages.xlf` again. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 8.0.0-beta.16
Node: 11.11.0
OS: darwin x64

Issues.Title: generate classes and export it as a default
Issues.Body:
when running the following cmd:
`> ng g class test `

the generated class is
`export default class{..}`
instead of
`export class TestClass{}`
so it is more convenient when importing it
or at least add an option to the command
`> ng g class test --default-export=true `
also applied to components and other ng elements

Issues.Title: Add experimentalImportFactories when migrating to loadChildren import syntax
Issues.Body:
The https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/14181 migration also needs to add `"experimentalImportFactories": true` to `angular.json` (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/13948) to make the import syntax supported in VE. 

The tsconfig file should also be updated to use `"module": "esnext"`, and a e2e test should be added to test the update works and an app with lazy routes will be updated and runs properly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add experimentalImportFactories when migrating to loadChildren import syntax" (#14218)

Issues.Title: feat: Rename angular.json to workspace.json
Issues.Body:
# Rename angular.json to workspace.json

## Description

The Angular CLI/ Angular Devkit is a generic tool which is extensible to do almost anything. Having the workspace information stored in `angular.json` is a misnomer as it is possible to have non-Angular projects and builders defined there. 

## Describe the solution you'd like

With the new Workspace API, storage of the workspace configuration is abstracted. It would be great to support a more agnostic config file such as `workspace.json` or `projects.json`. 

Currently, folks can already build node apps or web-components apps in an Angular CLI workspace, but the naming of the configuration file deters folks from doing it.

One of the best things about the Angular community is how well we collaborate with other communities. Having the CLI to be more generic and used in those communities will reinforce this.

The `angular.json` file could be supported for backward compatibility. This would improve the experience for doing things outside of Angular within a workspace.

## Describe alternatives you've considered

An alternative could be creating a separate CLI altogether such as the NestJS CLI but it would be great to have 1 agnostic CLI since the Angular CLI is capable of doing both.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat: Rename angular.json to workspace.json" (#14204)

Issues.Title: breakpointObserver incorrectly emits when resizing
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
If multiple breakpoints are provided, the observer should only emit "false" if neither breakpoint is matched

#### What is the current behavior?
If multiple breakpoints are provided and quick resizing occurs, the observer sometimes emits "false" despite the size never leaving the matched range.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
in [this stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/query-size-bug?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts), resize the window quickly at around 600px width. If you never go over the "Small" breakpoint size, the results of "betterLargeMatches" (which uses a single query) does not increment, but the value of `largeMatches` does sometimes increment.


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Reproduced in Safari and Chrome on MacOS, using CDK 7.3.x and Angular 7.2.x. I have not tested with other versions.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
This issue is particularly bad when a layout change happens based on the breakpoint observer, and if that layout change involves adding or removing components. For example, I found this bug in a layout that has two columns at large sizes, but a mat-tab component at small sizes. This bug caused the mat-tab to reinitialize when the window was resized from XSmall to Small, which caused the state of the currently active tab to be lost.

The workaround is to create a single query that encompasses both queries (as shown in the stackblitz)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "breakpointObserver incorrectly emits when resizing" (#15868)

Issues.Title: [MatStepper] FormControlLike is not compatible with FormGroup
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
The stepControl attribute of the CdkStep/MatStep classes should be castable to/assignable from a FormGroup or FormArray.

#### What is the current behavior?
`Conversion of type 'FormControlLike' to type 'FormGroup' may be a mistake because neither type sufficiently overlaps with the other. If this was intentional, convert the expression to 'unknown' first.
Property 'controls' is missing in type 'FormControlLike'.`
Happens during compilation when trying to cast FormControlLike to a FormGroup.

```Type FormGroup is not assignable to type FormControlLike```
Is the warning shown in HTML files when trying to assign a FormGroup to the stepControl input of a MatStep.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Create a MatStepper with a FormGroup assigned to a stepControl of one of the MatSteps. To reproduce the compilation issue, try to cast the stepControl of one step into a FormGroup within a TypeScript function.


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

Issues.Title: Virtual scroller doesn't disconnect DataSource when destroyed
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
If the cdkVirtualFor's data input is a DataSource, it should be disconnected upon directive's destruction.

#### What is the current behavior?
If the cdkVirtualFor's data input is a DataSource, it's never disconnected upon directive's destruction.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Just open this [stackblitz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fstackblitz.com%2Fedit%2Fangular-r7faxt&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNGcIMIlM24RETc_INmfoYL9uhFhPg) and toggle virtual scroller in and out of the view multiple times. Check the console, and you'll only see the data source connection messages. It never gets disconnected. This will cause leaks if, for example, the data source subscribes to some service in order to fetch data from backend.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
The very last Angular Material v7.3.7.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
This is the piece of code, related to the data source disconnection logic:

![scroller](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34121107/56340795-b1b94b00-61bb-11e9-990a-b725cba2e726.png)

And here's a [link](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fangular%2Fmaterial2%2Fblob%2Fmaster%2Fsrc%2Fcdk%2Fscrolling%2Fvirtual-for-of.ts%23L269&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNHcGvIsWTegNK0YauLgEvv_i9KyUg) to this snippet. It's the only place where the data source gets disconnected. In other words, the data source is only disconnected if the data source changes. Hence the issue, mentioned above:  the disconnect() method isn't called upon directive's destruction.

If there's nothing I'm missing it should be easy to fix - the data source should be disconnected in cdkVirtualFor's **ngOnDestroy** method if the input is a DataSource.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Virtual scroller doesn't disconnect DataSource when destroyed" (#15855)

Issues.Title: [MatIcon] can not be embedded in SVGs
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Bug

#### What is the expected behavior?
MatIcon or equivalent should be able to be embedded via an ng-container tag so that SVG
icons render only SVG tags.

#### What is the current behavior?

Mat icons are always surrounded by a <mat-icon> tag which prevents svgIcons from rendering
when embedded in an svg.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

https://material2-issue-15045-ijytdc.stackblitz.io

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?

We are building a SVG based visualization library in Angular and I would rather not create my
own icon component. SVG icons should be embeddable in an SVG.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

All

#### Is there anything else we should know?

Th example has an inherited svg-icon component that I created. Because of some of the
internals of mat-icon I would rather material provide a fix instead of my app having to deal with breaking changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[MatIcon] can not be embedded in SVGs" (#15854)

Issues.Title: radio button checked when it shouldn't be
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
I have a set of radio buttons in a radio button group.  I try to set the 'checked' property based on a specific value. 

#### What is the current behavior?
Sometimes the radio button will be checked when it specifically shouldn't be.  Doesn't happen all the time.  I am wonder if this is a caching issue or possibly a bug?


#### What are the steps to reproduce?
<mat-radio-group class="radio-group" formControlName="answerId">
 <mat-radio-button (click)="captureAnswer(qAnswer)"  class="radio-button" 
                            *ngFor="let qAnswer of Question,let i = index" [value]="qAnswer.answer_id" checked="{{qAnswer.answered === 1}}" [name]="i">{{qAnswer.answer}}  (Trying to set checked property to:  {{qAnswer.answered}})
          </mat-radio-button>
        </mat-radio-group>


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

Issues.Title: MatMenu positioning wrong when scale != 100%
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
The MatMenu positions itself on the trigger as expected

#### What is the current behavior?
Normally it positions correctly, BUT if screen scaling is applied (either by Windows screen setting or by using Chrome scaling with CTRL+"+" or CTRL+"-") it positions itself quite randomly.
I debugged it a little bit and the viewPort ruler/rect variables are set correct (i.e. 1536x756 on a 1920x1080 resolution with 125% scaling; which is pretty standard on laptops), but when it sets the pixels on style attribute, it top and left position are scaled to 1920px.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular 7.2.13, Angular Material 7.2.2 and 7.3.7 (tried both), Windows 10, "Chrome 73.0.3683.103 (Official Build) (64-bit)", Typescript 3.1.6

#### Is there anything else we should know?
The menu component is builded dynamically (with ComponentFactoryResolver etc) and the same menu might be attached to multiple triggers positioned in different positions.
Also such triggers are inside foreignObjects created on a d3.js graph
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatMenu positioning wrong when scale != 100%" (#15845)
